entry.title: SAP Master Data Integration (MDI): SAP S/4HANA Business Partner Replication using DRF Customizing
entry.content:
Introduction

This blog builds on our earlier post on SAP MDI Architecture and Deployment. Here, we explore end-to-end configuration for replicating Business Partner data from an SAP S/4HANA system to SAP Master Data Integration (MDI) using SOAP-based communication and DRF (Data Replication Framework).

Prerequisites

Ensure the following are in place:

  • SAP MDI service instance and service key created in SAP BTP Cockpit
  • DRF enabled in the S/4HANA system
  • Role-based access to SOAMANAGER
  • Active connectivity between SAP BTP and On-Premises via SAP Cloud Connector

DRF Configuration

  • In DRFIMG, create a Business System with BO Type and Communication System "Replication via Services" for the object "986" for Business Partner including Relationships.
  • Ensure the Business System ID matches the one used in the MDO configuration to avoid integration errors.
  • Assign Outbound Implementation "986_3 Outbound Implementation for BP/REL via Services", Assign Target System and Outbound Parameters under "Define Replication Models".
  • Repeat steps above for Key Mapping as 1376 if the integration scenario requires key mapping replication.

 WSDL Setup via SOAMANAGER

Download WSDLs

  • Download 6 WSDLs as per SAP Note 2987243

Customize and Upload
  • Now we have the below 6 WSDL Files:
    BusinessPartnerSUITEBulkReplicateRequest_Out
    BusinessPartnerSUITEBulkReplicateConfirmation_Out
    BusinessPartnerRelationshipSUITEBulkReplicateRequest_Out
    BusinessPartnerRelationshipSUITEBulkReplicateConfirmation_Out
    KeyMappingBulkReplicateRequest_Out
    KeyMappingBulkReplicateConfirmation_Out
  • Add the following elements at the end of each of the WSDL Files before the </wsdl:definitions> tag.
  • It is important to note that the below XML element contains a sample SAP Master Data Integration Endpoint.
    <wsdl:service name="...">
    <wsdl:port name="..." binding="...">
    <soap:address location="https://<uri>:443/businesspartner/v0/soap/BusinessPartnerRelationshipBulkReplicateRequestConfirmIn?tenantId=<identity_zone>" />
    </wsdl:port>
    </wsdl:service>
  • You need to replace this with your Master Data Integration details for all of them.
    The SAP Master Data Integration Endpoint is of the following pattern:<uri>:443/businesspartner/v0/soap/BusinessPartnerRelationshipBulkReplicateRequestConfirmIn?tenantId=<identity_zone>
    In the above pattern:
    URI is equal to the value of attribute ‚Äúuri‚Äù in your Master Data Integration instance‚Äôs service key
    identity_zone is equal to the value of attribute ‚Äúidentity zone‚Äù in your Master Data Integration instance‚Äôs service key
    Example for 1 WSDL- https://one.mds.cfapps.sap.hana.ondemand.com:443/businesspartner/v0/soap/BusinessPartnerRelationshipBulkReplicateRequestConfirmIn?tenantId=mdibpconsumer1
  • Upload all 6 WSDLs in SOA Management

Publish WSDLs to Services Registry

  • Use Services Registry ‚Üí Publication of External WSDL
  • Assign appropriate internal names, bindings, and physical systems
  • Reuse the physical system object across all WSDLs after first creation

MDI System Access Profile

  • Go to Technical Administration ‚Üí Profiles
  • Create a new profile with:
    Auth: User ID/Password
    Transport: Secured communication
  • Link this profile to the provider system using the same Business System ID as DRF

Logon Data Management

  • Go to Service Administration ‚Üí Logon Data Management
  • Create credentials using:
    clientId as username
    clientSecret as password from the MDI service key

Local Integration Scenario Configuration

  • Go to Local Integration Scenario Configuration
  • Add these service groups:
    MDG_BS_SUPPLIERREPLICATEREQ
    MDG_BS_SUPPLIERREPLICATECONF
    KEY_MAP_REPLICATE_REQ
    KEY_MAP_REPLICATE_CONF

  • Assign IBC Reference to each from the MDI system
  • Link all service groups to the created Logon Data

Activate Logical Ports

  • Go to Service Administration ‚Üí Pending Tasks
  • Process all pending tasks
  • Validate port creation via Web Service Configuration

SOAP Endpoint Setup for MDI

  • Go to Web Service Configuration
  • For each of the 6 service definitions (e.g. BUSINESSPARTNERSUITEBULKREPLIC), create a service binding
  • Under ‚ÄúTransport Settings‚Äù, copy the Calculated Access URL
  • Final endpoint:
    https://<host>:<port>/<calculated_access_url>
    Example: 
    https://ldciemt.wdf.sap.corp:44322/sap/bc/srt/xip/sap/businesspartnersuitebulkreplic/405/mdibpconsumer11/binding8

This URL is then used to configure the BPOUTBOUND destination in your BTP subaccount.

Conclusion

With this setup complete, your S/4HANA system is now capable of replicating Business Partner master data to SAP MDI in real-time via push or pull mechanisms. You‚Äôve established secure communication, configured service groups, and integrated SOAP endpoints ‚Äî ensuring a robust and scalable MDI architecture.
Please note the Blog is to connect S/4HANA on-prem/Private Cloud system to MDI, there can be more scenario where the MDI would be then connected to other systems. For such scenarios, configuration is required in Master Data Orchestration or Business Data Orchestration.

entry.title: Why SAP ISA-M Still Matters ‚Äì A Strategic Foundation for Modern Integration
entry.content:
In the era of APIs, hybrid landscapes, and cloud-native development, it's easy to assume that methodologies like SAP ISA-M (Integration Solution Advisory Methodology) are outdated. But the truth is: ISA-M is more relevant than ever. It remains a strategic compass for defining and implementing integration architectures that are sustainable, business-aligned, and tool-agnostic.

 

üîç What is SAP ISA-M?

SAP ISA-M is a structured methodology that helps enterprises define their integration strategy, classify integration use cases, and select the right technologies and governance models. It supports decision-making across cloud, hybrid, and on-premise landscapes ‚Äì regardless of whether you‚Äôre using SAP Integration Suite, SAP Advanced Event Mesh, or third-party platforms.

üîë Why ISA-M Still Matters Today

  1. Strategic Guidance for Cloud Transformation

ISA-M is widely used during S/4HANA and RISE with SAP transformations to assess legacy middleware (e.g., PI/PO) and design modern, API- and event-driven target architectures.

  1. Technology-Agnostic by Design

ISA-M is not tied to specific products. It provides a framework for integration strategy, which remains valid even as tools evolve ‚Äì from SAP Process Orchestration to SAP Integration Suite and beyond.

  1. Use Case-Driven Approach

By analyzing integration needs across five integration styles (e.g., process integration, data integration, event-driven integration), ISA-M helps teams design purposeful and scalable architectures.

  1. Connecting Business and IT

The methodology fosters collaboration between business owners, architects, and integration teams ‚Äì ensuring that integration becomes a business enabler, not just a technical necessity.

 

Where ISA-M is Used Today

‚úÖ Cloud Transformations & RISE with SAP

‚úÖ Modernization of Legacy Interfaces

‚úÖ Enablement & Governance Models

It outlines the phases in a modernization journey‚ÄîReview, Scope and Define Use Cases‚Äîand shows how to transition towards a future-ready, hybrid integration platform.

  • Assess Integration Strategy
  • Review Existing Integration Architecture
  • Scope and Define Best Practices and Target Architecture
  • Give power to the people

 

üöÄ Outlook: What‚Äôs Next for ISA-M?

üîß 1. ISA-M in INTAS ‚Äì SAP Integration Assessment Service

SAP‚Äôs INTAS (Integration Assessment Service) is a structured offering to help customers evaluate and modernize their integration landscape. ISA-M provides the core methodology behind this service:

  • Assessment of legacy and custom interfaces
  • Mapping use cases to modern SAP Integration Suite capabilities
  • Tailored modernization roadmap aligned to Clean Core principles

With INTAS, organizations benefit from a guided modernization plan that is both strategic and executable.

I will give you some more insights in on of our upcoming Integration Modernization expert sessions: https://events.sap.com/expertsession-isam/en_us/home.html

üîó 2. ISA-M and the SAP Integrated Toolchain

The SAP Integrated Toolchain for Modernization Projects combines multiple SAP tools and services, such as:

  • SAP Cloud ALM
  • SAP Signavio
  • SAP LeanIX
  • SAP WalkMe
  • SAP BTP ( with our focus on Integration Suite)

We us ISA-M acts as a strategic layer below the toolchain, ensuring that all activities ‚Äì from modeling to implementation ‚Äì follow a consistent integration strategy. For example:

  • LeanIX is the central tool for your overall Enterprise Architecture  ‚Üí ISA-M will help to control technologies and applications along the concept and to establish a government model
  • Signavio is used to model business processes ‚Üí ISA-M helps derive integration patterns
  • SAP Integration Suite itself can be used to integrate the toolchain (itself) ‚Üí ISA-M ensures style and governance fit, e.g. usage of SAP Advanced Event Mesh in combination with LeanIX Webhooks.

ISA-M connects the dots, providing strategic continuity across the entire toolchain.

We are currently working out an Integration Modernization expert which will give the required insights how you can implement it. Stay tune and follow our journey here https://events.sap.com/eur-sap-integration-modernization-expert-sessions/en_us/home.html

You would like to practice (e.g. with Integration content)? Just let me know.

üßº  3. ISA-M and Clean Core

Clean Core is one of the key guiding principles in SAP‚Äôs modernization strategy. But a Clean Core isn‚Äôt just about avoiding modifications ‚Äì it‚Äôs about separating business logic from system logic and creating modular, scalable architectures.

Here‚Äôs how ISA-M supports a Clean Core approach:

  • Recommends using APIs, events, and standardized integration styles
  • Avoids hard-coded dependencies between systems
  • Encourages centralized governance and reuse of services

By following ISA-M, companies are not just modernizing their interfaces ‚Äì they are actively cleaning their core.

 We hosted a first session how ISA-M can help you to ensure a clean-core approach Find the recording here: https://dam.sap.com/mac/app/e/video/embed/vAemLss?ltr=a&rc=10&doi=SAP1206809&includeSapBrandedWraper=true&includeRelatedAssets=true

 

‚úÖ Final Thoughts

Integration is no longer just a technical challenge ‚Äì it‚Äôs a strategic business discipline. And while the tools and technologies evolve, the need for a methodical, business-aligned integration strategy remains constant.

That‚Äôs why ISA-M continues to be a critical success factor for integration modernization, clean core transformation, and cloud-centric architectures.

Whether you're just starting your transformation journey or reviewing an existing landscape, ISA-M gives you the structure, language, and clarity to do it right.

üëâ Explore more:

  • ISA-M GitHub Repository
  • ISA-M Mission in SAP Discovery Center

 You need support? Send us a mail SAP Integration Modernization <integration.modernization@sap.com>

entry.title: SAP Master Data Integration (MDI) ‚Äì Bank and Cost Center Replication from S/4HANA
entry.content:
In continuation of my previous blogs on MDI Architecture and Deployment and Business Partner Replication, this post focuses on Bank and Cost Center replication from an SAP S/4HANA system to SAP Master Data Integration (MDI).

Master Data objects like Banks and Cost Centers are foundational across multiple systems. Enabling seamless replication to MDI ensures a harmonized master data landscape, supporting a clean core and extensible architecture.

Common Configuration Steps

Before configuring the replication-specific models, there are common prerequisites applicable to both Bank and Cost Center integration. These ensure secured, authenticated communication and connectivity between S/4HANA and MDI.

1. OAuth 2.0 Client Configuration

Use transaction OA2C_CONFIG to configure your OAuth 2.0 client. This allows S/4HANA to authenticate securely with the SAP MDI service.

2. Create RFC Destination

Use transaction SM59 to create a destination pointing to MDI, essential for connectivity.

3. Configure MDI Destination

Use transaction S_SAL_71000052 to access view V_MDI_DEST_CONF and configure your destination here.

4. BGRFC Configuration

Set up Inbound BGRFC Destinations using SBGRFCCONF. This ensures reliable communication for asynchronous data transfers.

5. Extract AIF Content

Run /AIF/CONTENT_EXTRACT with SAP_COM_0659 to extract the content needed for integration scenarios.

6. Publish OData V4 Services

Use /IWFND/V4_ADMIN to publish OData V4 service groups if not already done.

7. Create Technical User

Use SU01 to create a user that will be used for background processing and secure calls.

8. Assign Required Role

Clone the role SAP_CA_DRF_MDO using PFCG and assign it to the technical user created above.

9. Configure SAP BTP Destination

Ensure the destination is correctly set in the SAP BTP Cockpit pointing to your S/4HANA On-Prem system.

Cost Center Replication Setup

A. Push Model Configuration

Configure a push model to automatically send data to MDI when a Cost Center is created or changed.

B. Pull Model Testing

To validate the integration, use a REST client such as Postman to pull data from MDI after the Push model replicates it.

Sample replicated Cost Center data can be verified in Postman once changes are triggered from S/4HANA.

C. Output Test

Bank Replication Setup

A. Push Model Configuration

Similar to Cost Center, set up a Push Model for Banks to send data changes automatically to MDI.

B. Pull Model Testing

Again, Postman can be used as a mock target system to verify the successful pull of replicated bank data from MDI.

C. Output Test

Summary

With this setup, you‚Äôve now enabled real-time or near-real-time replication of Bank and Cost Center data from S/4HANA to SAP MDI, supporting both Push and Pull models. This ensures data consistency across systems and promotes a modular, scalable enterprise data architecture.

Please note the Blog is to connect S/4HANA on-prem/Private Cloud system to MDI, there can be more scenario where the MDI would be then connected to other systems. For such scenarios, configuration is required in Master Data Orchestration or Business Data Orchestration.

entry.title: Optimized IDoc Routing in SAP CI with Value Mapping and Groovy-Based Receiver Determination
entry.content:
Target Audience

This blog is primarily intended for the SAP Integration community seeking a strategy for routing outbound IDoc flows from SAP ECC or S/4HANA systems‚Äîparticularly for those migrating from SAP PI/PO to SAP Cloud Integration (Formerly known as SAP Cloud Platform Integration or SAP CPI) and exploring effective alternatives to implement the same.

Motivation

In traditional SAP PI/PO-based landscapes, routing outbound IDocs from SAP ECC or S/4HANA systems is straightforward. A single t-RFC destination and IDoc port are typically configured in the sender system to forward all IDocs to SAP PI. Within SAP PI, routing is managed efficiently using the Integration Directory and centralized runtime (AEX), enabling reuse of a single IDoc destination across multiple interfaces and message types (MATMAS, INVOIC, DEBMAS, etc).

However, when migrating to SAP Cloud Integration, this simplicity is disrupted. Cloud Integration does not provide an equivalent mechanism for managing IDoc traffic using a central gateway or common destination. Instead, each interface often requires its own unique endpoint, destination, and port, making the configuration effort redundant and makes IDoc Routing complex  and operationally challenging, as part of this blog I wanted to tackle these challenges and simplify this. (* I wont go into the specific challenges of the different approches and rather focus on the problems I am trying to solve in the current approach)

 

Solution Approach:

As described in the flow above, we will implement the design using two iFlows:

  • IF_SAP_to_Generic_IDOCRouting:
    This iFlow receives IDoc XML messages from various SAP systems. It is responsible for receiver determination and routes the message to the appropriate target iFlow based on routing logic.
    In SAP PI/PO terminology, this iFlow handles the Inbound Processing and Receiver Determination steps of the integration pipeline.

  • IF_SAP_to_<Receiver>_<Interface Description>:
    This iFlow is specific to the receiver system and handles transformation, mapping, and other receiver-specific processing.
    In SAP PI/PO terms, this iFlow corresponds to the Interface Determination and Outbound Processing steps of the integration pipeline.

IF_SAP_to_Generic_IDOCRouting

Step 1: Extract Details from EDI_DC40 of IDoc xml and create Exchange properties: 

The IDoc routing in this flow primarily relies on Value Mappings and Groovy scripts. In this step, the necessary inputs and variables are initialized‚Äîthese are later used in Groovy script execution to extract routing details from the configured Value Mappings.

For example, consider a sender system Q10 (the quality environment of the x10 SAP system with client number 001) sending an INVOIC IDoc with an extension type ZINVOIC01. The properties are initialized as below.

                                    

The sentReceiverCount variable is initialized to zero and is later used during processing when the same IDoc meets conditions for multiple receivers, ensuring it is sent to each applicable receiver accordingly.

Step 2: Fetch Receiver List for the IDOC from the Value Mapping tables using Exchange properties:

For this we would need to maintain two value mappings

Value Mapping for Sender Partner Number to Sender Identifier Conversion:

As an example, I have maintained the details of SAP systems x10 and x20 across their Development, Quality, and Production environments. You would similarly maintain all relevant SAP systems and their corresponding identifiers in the Value Mapping used for IDoc routing. This mapping typically requires updates only when new SAP systems are added or existing systems are migrated (when SIDs change), which are relatively infrequent events.

Value Mapping for ReceiverList, Receiver Determination and Receiver Target IFlow URls:

The second Value Mapping is maintained for each unique combination of SAP sender system and IDoc type.
For example, to define receiver determination conditions for the IDOC: INVOIC.INVOIC01.ZINVOIC01 sent from the SAP system x10, you would create a corresponding Value Mapping entry as shown below.

The ValueMapping will have 3 Mapping with agency as x10.INVOIC.INVOIC01.ZINVOIC01 (sender Identifier.IDOC)

IDOCName to ReceiverList : This mapping holds a list of all receivers applicable for a specific IDoc.

ReceiverName to ReceiverCondition: This defines the receiver determination condition for each receiver. The conditions should be maintained using XPath expressions to evaluate the IDoc content dynamically.

ReceiverName to ReceiverIFlowAddress: This maps each receiver to the endpoint URL of its corresponding integration flow (IF_SAP_to_<Receiver>_<Interface Description>) , as described earlier in the solution approach.

Now that we've covered how the Value Mappings are maintained, let‚Äôs look at how the Groovy script fetches the appropriate values:

1. Fetch senderIdentifier
The senderIdentifier is retrieved using the exchange property senderPartnerNumber (set in step 1). This value is looked up from the first ValueMapping.
Example:
If a message is sent from system Q10 with sender partner number Q10_001, the senderIdentifier fetched from the Value Mapping would be x10.

2. Construct Agency Key
Using the senderIdentifier and other exchange properties (set in step 1), the agency key is constructed. This key will be used to retrieve routing information from the second ValueMapping.
Agency Format:
<senderIdentifier>.<messageType>.<IDocType>[.<extensionType>]
     senderIdentifier ‚Äì from first Value Mapping
     messageType ‚Äì from exchange property
     IDocType ‚Äì from exchange property
     extensionType ‚Äì from exchange property (optional)
Example:
For an INVOIC IDoc of type INVOIC01 with extension ZINVOIC01 sent from system x10, the agency would be: x10.INVOIC.INVOIC01.ZINVOIC01

3. Fetch Receiver List
Using the constructed agency key, the receiver list is retrieved from the second ValueMapping.
Example:
For the agency x10.INVOIC.INVOIC01.ZINVOIC01, the receiver list will be:
Receiver1, Receiver2, Receiver3
Value Mapping sample call:

valueMapApi.getMappedValue(
  'x10.INVOIC.INVOIC01.ZINVOIC01', 'IDOCName', 
  'INVOIC.INVOIC01.ZINVOIC01', 'x10.INVOIC.INVOIC01.ZINVOIC01', 
  'ReceiverList')

Step3: Execute Receiver Determination Conditions (Groovy Script) from Value Mapping

The Groovy script then iterates through the receiver list, fetching the corresponding receiver determination condition for each receiver and evaluating it against the IDoc content using XPath.

// Fetch condition from Value Mapping
currentReceiverCondition = valueMapApi.getMappedValue(
  'x10.INVOIC.INVOIC01.ZINVOIC01',
  'ReceiverName',
  'Receiver1',
  'x10.INVOIC.INVOIC01.ZINVOIC01',
  'ReceiverCondition'
)
// Evaluate condition
def expr = xpath.compile(currentReceiverCondition as String)
def result = expr.evaluate(doc, XPathConstants.BOOLEAN)

If the condition evaluates to true, the receiver is added to the exchange property determinedReceivers. A counter variable determinedReceiverCount is also maintained to track how many receivers matched successfully.

At the end of this step, three additional exchange properties will be available: determinedReceivers, determinedReceiverCount, and IDOCName (which holds the constructed agency key).

In the example discussed, lets consider if the conditions are satisfied for Receiver2 and Receiver3, then the determinedReceivers list will contain both, and the determinedReceiverCount will be set to 2.
The IDOCName property (i.e., the agency key: x10.INVOIC.INVOIC01.ZINVOIC01) is also stored to be reused in subsequent steps of the flow.

Step 4: Send Message to Receiver Specific flow for the  Determined Receivers 

In this step, a looping process call is executed, which repeatedly invokes a local integration process to send the message to each receiver identified in the previous step‚Äîone at a time.

The property sentReceiverCount is incremented after each message is successfully sent to a determined receiver. The loop continues until sentReceiverCount equals determinedReceiverCount, at which point the process terminates.

To send the message to a specific receiver, a Groovy script is used to retrieve the receiver name from the determinedReceivers list. Using this name, the script fetches the endpoint URL of the corresponding receiver-specific iFlow from the second ValueMapping.

Value Mapping sample call:

valueMapApi.getMappedValue(
  'x10.INVOIC.INVOIC01.ZINVOIC01', 
  'IDOCName', 
  'INVOIC.INVOIC01.ZINVOIC01', 
  'x10.INVOIC.INVOIC01.ZINVOIC01', 
  'ReceiverIFlowAddress'
)

The fetched endpoint URL is then assigned to the header property receiverProcessDirectURL, which is used by the ProcessDirect adapter to route the message to the appropriate receiver-specific iFlow. IF_SAP_to_<Receiver>_<Interface Description> which would handle  transformation, mapping, and other receiver-specific processing.

 

Advantages of the Proposed IDoc Routing Strategy in SAP Cloud Integration

 The strategy outlined in this blog offers a scalable, modular, and maintainable alternative that aligns closely with enterprise integration requirements. Below are the key advantages of this design:

1. Reusability of Integration Flows

Instead of creating a separate iFlow for each IDoc-to-receiver combination, this approach separates:
Generic routing logic (IF_SAP_to_Generic_IDOCRouting)
Receiver-specific logic(IF_SAP_to_<Receiver>_<Interface>)
Benefit: Reduces development effort and avoids duplication across iFlows, enabling a clean and modular architecture.

2. Centralized Routing with Value Mappings

Routing conditions and receiver lists are managed through Value Mapping artifacts.
Benefit: Updates to routing logic can be done without modifying or redeploying iFlows‚Äîjust update the Value Mapping configuration.

3. Scalable Across Systems and IDoc Variants

Routing logic is built dynamically using:
- Sender system identifier
- Message type
- IDoc type
- (Optional) Extension type
Benefit: Supports complex multi-system, multi-IDoc scenarios without inflating the number of artifacts or flows.

4. Native Support for Multi-Receiver Scenarios

The use of Groovy logic and looping constructs enables routing to multiple receivers based on evaluated XPath conditions.
Benefit: Enables 1:n routing scenarios, ensuring the same IDoc can be routed to multiple receivers without message duplication logic.

5. Low Maintenance and High Adaptability

This architecture requires Value Mapping updates only when:
- New SAP systems are added
- Existing systems are migrated
- Additional receiver conditions are introduced
Benefit: Minimal maintenance effort over time; no need for frequent design or deployment changes.

6. Aligned with SAP PI/PO Routing Model

The flow structure mirrors familiar SAP PI/PO pipeline steps, such as:
- Receiver Determination
- Interface Determination
- Outbound Processing
Benefit: Simplifies migration for teams transitioning from SAP PI/PO to SAP CI, while preserving key routing concepts. Also there is a scope for automation where you could write a code to automate creation of Valuemapping. The existing  ports can be reused by updating the RFC destination pointing to the SAP CI 

This approach attempts to addresses the Technical limitations of SAP CI‚Äôs IDoc handling, and also supports sustainable growth and cleaner and maintainable integration landscapes.

Additional Considerations for Retry and Reprocessing

  1. Retry and error handling should be implemented within each receiver-specific flow to manage failures independently for every receiver.

  2. It is advisable to avoid broadcasting IDocs directly from SAP Cloud Integration, especially in high-volume scenarios like master data distribution across multiple systems. This is due to potential limitations in storing failed messages within the SAP Cloud Integration tenant. Additionally, in broadcast cases, the retry mechanism should support resending only to the receivers where failures occurred, not all recipients.

  3. Exceptions can be returned to the sender system (e.g., via SOAP fault) so that errors are reflected in the originating SAP system(Return Exception to Sender ). This enables visibility in transaction logs like WE02/WE05, helping to identify and reprocess failed IDocs more effectively.

  4. Batch jobs in the SAP backend responsible for reprocessing IDocs should be adjusted based on the new failure status codes introduces by this setup

 

Conclusion

This blog attempted to present a scalable, maintainable, modular and  operationally efficient strategy for receiver determination of outbound IDocs from SAP system by leveraging Groovy script and Value Mapping. Also by decoupling the routing and receiver-specific logic into two separate iFlows, the solution ensures better reusability, easier maintenance, and greater control over message processing.

entry.title: Clean Core by Design: Using SAP Advanced Event Mesh (AEM) as the First Principle
entry.content:
In the digital era of today where digital transformation is every organization‚Äôs need, SAP Clean Core Principle is more than just a word, it's a among the foundational principle for enterprises looking to future-proof their SAP landscape. As per the SAP clean core approach, where technology is moving towards API first Approach, modular architectures, the organizations must decouple their custom logic instead of the application server to external API‚Äôs outside the application server layer to ensure agility, scalability, and reducing the upgrade complexity.

One of the most powerful enablers of this Clean Core approach is the event driven architecture through SAP Advanced Event Mesh (AEM), an enterprise-grade event brokering solution that supports real-time, event-driven architectures across hybrid landscapes.

In this blog, I‚Äôll walk you through how to achieve Clean Core by adopting AEM as the first principle, laying the groundwork for a decoupled, scalable, and intelligent enterprise.

 The Clean Core Strategy ‚Äî What and Why?

  1. Avoid Extensions where not required
  2. Upgrades should not interfere with the extensions and extensions should not interfere with the upgrades
  3. Decouple the extensions from the Standard
  4. Keep the custom code separate from the S4 Core

A Clean Code

The Clean Core strategy focuses on:

  • Keeping custom code, extensions, and integrations outside the SAP S/4HANA digital core.
  • Leveraging side-by-side extensibility using SAP BTP.
  • Using stable APIs and events to communicate between systems and layers.

This approach ensures that your core ERP remains clean, lean, and easily upgradeable‚Äîan essential factor for reducing TCO and accelerating innovation cycles.

In short, minimize extensions, decouple them from the standard, build side-by-side extensions on the BTP layer without touching the S4 HANA Core.

 Why AEM as the First Principle?

To achieve the clean core strategy, event driven architecture plays an important role by decoupling the processes through individual events, following the loosely couple framework and avoiding tightly coupled integrations.

SAP Advanced Event Mesh enables event-driven architecture (EDA) that decouples the source of truth (S/4HANA, SuccessFactors, C4C, etc.) from consumers (external apps, extensions, APIs). Here's why it's foundational to Clean Core:

  • Asynchronous Communication: No tight coupling between systems.
  • Loose Integration: Replace point-to-point interfaces with publish-subscribe models.
  • Extensibility: Let consumers build side-by-side extensions without modifying the core.
  • Scalability: Support multiple consumers with minimal configuration overhead.

 Clean Core in Action ‚Äî Event-Driven Architecture with AEM

Let‚Äôs take a simple example: BP Onboarding in SAP S/4.

 Without Clean Core (Tightly Coupled):

  1. Custom ABAP enhancements in S/4HANA to trigger BP Creation/ Change Events.
  2. Direct API calls or IDoc triggers to downstream applications like ARIBA/ C4C/ Hybris/ External Applications from S/4.
  3. Every new consumer or change = new code or regression testing.

 With Clean Core (Using AEM):

  1. S/4 HANA triggers the BP Creation Event via Event Enablement Cockpit.
  2. AEM captures the events and routes it to all the subscribers.
  3. Subscribers (CPI, CAP apps, external systems) performs the required logic without modifying the core system.

No enhancement. No code in the core. Just events and clean extensions.

Common Use Cases Where AEM Drives Clean Core

  • Customer/Vendor Create in S/4HANA ‚Üí Event to AEM ‚Üí Update CRM/External apps.
  • Purchase Order Created ‚Üí Event routed via AEM ‚Üí Notify suppliers via external systems.
  • Material Master Update ‚Üí Trigger downstream analytics apps or warehouse systems.

entry.title: SAP RISE - Six Integration Patterns You‚Äôll Face
entry.content:
In one of my previous blogs Why SAP ISA-M Still Matters ‚Äì A Strategic Foundation for Modern Integration I have given some insights in which projects & situations I am currently using ISA-M to define my Integration patterns.  What should be more strategic then RISE nowadays?  

 

üß≠ The Integration Architect‚Äôs Dilemma in RISE Projects

It usually starts with excitement ‚Äî ‚ÄúWe‚Äôre moving to RISE!‚Äù. But as the Integration Architect, you feel a shift in the room once you ask:

‚ÄúHow will your business-critical integrations survive the move?‚Äù

‚ÄúHow will our Integration Patterns change in a Private Cloud Environment?‚Äù

‚ÄúDo we have to an option to be part of this modernization?‚Äù

In too many RISE conversations, integration is not part of initial phases , but everything depends on it. Whether you‚Äôre facing direct system-to-system integrations, legacy SAP PO platforms, or the modernization path toward Integration Suite and AEM: you need clarity.

 

Let‚Äôs talk about the 6 most common integration scenarios I encounter in RISE projects ‚Äî and let‚Äôs do a deep dive into one of them.

üìåContext: What Makes RISE Integration Different?

ISA-M allows us to talk in Integration patterns ‚Äî proven, repeatable ways to connect cloud, on-prem, and hybrid landscapes.

Draw your Integration landscape abstract as below and repeat the same for all Integration Domains and Integration Patterns, maybe Integration Styles. We focus on the common Process Integration patterns which often are.

üîç Scenario 1: On-Premise to On-Premise (e.g., existing ECC system ‚Üí S/4, within same on-prem datacenter)

üí¨ Comment:
This is often the existing baseline. When the customers still host their systems locally. No RISE adaption in this case

üîç Scenario 2: Private Cloud to Private Cloud (e.g., S/4 to S/4 Integration, within same RISE datacenter)

 

üîßTechnology in use:

  • SAP Integration Suite, Edge Cell on a Private Cloud hyperscaler, such as Azure or AWS 
  • VPN or direct peering within same hyperscaler
  • Azure VNet Peering, AWS VPC Peering, or similar as secure tunnel
  • *SAP Integration Suite, Edge Cell on On-Premise landscape ( e.g. on SUSE or Red Hat) is also a valid option

Differentiators

  • Usage of Application Interface Framework for S/4HANA Monitoring
  • Usage of transactions and APIM Management operations
  • Usage of SAP CALM for overall central Monitoring ( if applicable)

üîç Scenario 3: Private Cloud to Public Cloud (RISE workload connects to SaaS like SuccessFactors)

üí¨ Comment:

For hybrid Integration SAP Integration Suite could be used as natural entry point

üîç Scenario 4: Public Cloud to Public Cloud (e.g., SuccessFactors ‚Üî Ariba or Salesforce ‚Üî S/4 in RISE)

üí¨ Comment:
This is a modernization sweet spot. Cloud-native to cloud-native with no concrete RISE touchpoints.

üîç Scenario 5: On-Premise to Public Cloud

üí¨ Comment:
This is often the existing baseline. When the customers still host their backend systems locally but use SaaS applications for certain LoBs. No RISE adaption in this case

üîç Scenario 6: On-Premise to Private Cloud (e.g., ECC ‚Üí RISE in Azure, hybrid operation)

üí¨ Comment:
This hybrid pattern is very common in staged RISE transitions. Customers keep some systems on-prem while moving others (‚Äúearly adaptors) into RISE.

 

üîßModernization Reality Check

Most customers do one of three things:

  1. Move PO Interfaces to SAP Integration Suite, Cloud Integration  and SAP Integration Suite, Edge Cell  
  2. Modernize to SAP Advanced Event Mesh
  3. Use more featreus of the SAP Integration Suite, such as API Managmenet

So here‚Äôs what I recommend to every architect:

  • Audit your interface and integration technologies before RISE.
  • Classify interfaces using along the patterns in this blog.
  • Decide per pattern: Keep, Modernize, or Sunset.
  • Actively design your new integration landscape ‚Äî don‚Äôt wait for someone else to.

 

üìû Let‚Äôs Build Smarter RISE Integrations

I‚Äôve worked on numerous RISE integration journeys and built a reference architecture library covering each scenario. If you want to see the diagrams, dig into patterns, or compare your setup ‚Äî I‚Äôm happy to help.

entry.title: Let's demystify Event vs. Data Streaming in EDA
entry.content:
Event-Driven Architecture (EDA) is becoming increasingly more-an-more mainstream choice for the Integration Architecture approach. EDA seems to be a right choice for the modern Enterprises, aiming toward Composable Business and its agility. EDA can provide ‚ÄúDecoupled Integration‚Äù which is the essence of the Compossible Business way of thinking (as already elaborated, in my previous article)[1].

EDA should be considered as a key capability and thus included in any Enterprise Architecture transformation and modernization initiative. Of course, it‚Äôs not only EDA, but EDA is the core enabler for the Composable Business Architecture, because EDA supports:

  • Scalability
  • Flexibility
  • Resilience
  • Data quality

Figure 1. EDA and its role EA

EDA is what?

An Event-Driven Architecture is an integration model built to publish, capture, process, and respond to events across distributed systems in (near) real time[2]. It uses events to trigger and communicate between decoupled services and it is common in modern applications, which are built with microservices[3].

Because of its nature (i.e. PUSH data), EDA is very often referred to Event Streaming or Data Streaming. In specific cases, we may also refer to IoT Streaming. While this small ‚Äúmess‚Äù in the semantic and terminology is confusing, we are in fact always talking about the same ‚Äì we are talking about an Event Broker which is providing Event Choreography for all connected client system ‚Äì no matter if they are Source System(s) or Target System(s).

But what are we really talking about? Are we really providing Streaming of the Events or Data?

What is an Event?

In general terms, an Event is a thing that happens or takes place, usually with a particular importance. But it is just too broad definition. In the context of IT or OT, and EDA, we will consider that Event is any detectable occurrence or (significant) change in a system's state that can trigger a certain action. It is also discrete and immutable record of the change. In respect of EDA, we see that Event is basically a trigger for some Data (whether IT or IoT or IIoT etc.) to be pushed or published from the Source System toward Target System, which is subscribed to receive it. We are not really ‚Äúsending‚Äù an Event, we are always sending some Notification (or Data in general). Event is just a trigger.

If we talk about Business Systems, like SAP S/4HANA or similar, Event would be creation of the new Sales Order or change of the Sales Order line items or so. This change is a trigger for some action ‚Äì what action we are triggering this is different story‚Ä¶

  • We may send an Event Notification that new Sales Order line idem has been added, or some existing has been changed ‚Äì usually in a form a very short message, in SAP S/4HANA with so called CloudEvent. Sending a Notification is sometime designated as Event Streaming. Ordinarily, client system(s) may invoke a RESTful request to pull additional data from the source.
  • We may send Data Notification for the new Sales Order ‚Äì usually replicating full Data Record. Sending full Data Record is sometime also called Data Streaming, especially if we are replicating data from ERP System to i.e. some Analytical System or Data Lake (although this is in fact not a continuous stream of Data, but transmission of distinct Data Records based on the Business Event trigger). Ordinarily, we do not expect any response from the client system(s)
  • We may also send something in between, like Decision Notification where i.e. certain items in the Sales Order are not available (after ATP B check) but also sending a proposal of the replacement items ‚Äì usually this is small message payload carrying only minimum necessary data for the client system to make a ‚Äúdecision‚Äù. Here we do expect client system to make a ‚Äúdecision‚Äù and usually invoke some further processing in the ERP System.

SAP S/4HANA system supports many standard OOTB (Out-Of-The-Box) CloudEvents, and those are mostly Event Notifications[4].

Figure 2. Example of the Event Notifications

What is Data?

Generally accepted definition could be that Data is a collection of facts, figures, symbols, or descriptions that represent something, often used for analysis, reasoning, or decision-making. We are often referring to Data as something ‚Äúrow‚Äù; while we observe an Information as something which was produced out of the "raw-data" ‚Äì something which has Business ‚Äúmeaning‚Äù. From the perspective of EDA, in Business Systems like SAP S/4HANA or similar, Data is a Record or a Document (or a part of it) ‚Äì i.e. Sales Order, or Business Partner, or Accounting Document etc.

What is Streaming?

In the context of IT or OT, by pure ‚Äúunofficial‚Äù definition, Streaming is a continuous flow of Data from a Source System to a Target System, often processed in real-time as it arrives.

  • In the domain of IT, as indicated previously, Business Systems like SAP S/4HANA or similar, will not provide (usually) continuous flow of Data, but rather distinct messages containing specific i.e. Data Records or Documents. Even if we have huge number of messages, they would still be distinct messages being published as a result of some specific Business Event(s). Despite this, we are still (very often) using terms like Event Streaming or Data Streaming.
  • However, in the domain of OT (or IoT/IIoT), many machines or devices, can produce both (depending on the particular use-case): distinct Data based on specific Technical Events (i.e. monitoring alert or so); as well as continuous flow of Data (i.e. telemetry). In both cases we tend to call it IoT Streaming (or Edge Integration), although first use-case is more like ‚Äústandard‚Äù Event Notification.

When we talk about IoT Streaming, we usually talk about large or very large number of small messages being sent by the Source System (or Device), i.e. based on different sensor reading or so.

Figure 3. Example of the Telemetry Stream

Main integration models of EDA ‚Äì or just terminology ‚Äúmess‚Äù?

Is Event Notification the same as Event Streaming, and is this the same as Data Streaming?

Yes and no ‚Äì depends of the terminology one uses. Many companies and experts will continue using different terminologies ‚Äì although, thinking of the exactly the same thing. Somehow, I tend to agree with the terminology associated mostly with SAP Advanced Event Mesh (i.e. Event Notifications, Data Notifications and Decision Notifications) supplemented with some IoT specific (i.e. IoT Notification/Command and IoT Streaming), where each of the "integration models" describes the actual integration scenario/use-case. However, as it usually happens, in daily communication we all tend to generalize (or simplify) too much ‚Äì using Event/Data Streaming to describe all EDA "integration models" seams to be a move in this direction. 

To make things at least a bit easier, let me try to share ‚Äúsome‚Äù high level mapping, of terminology, often used in various SAP Advanced Event Mesh papers, to other (simplified) terminology, often used by Gartner and some other organizations (although Gartner has its own split of EDA integration models):

Terminology

Triggered by

Other terminology

Event Notification

Business Event

Event Streaming

Data Notification

Business Event

Event or Data Streaming

Decision Notification

Business Event

Event Streaming

IoT Notification.
IoT Command

Technical Event

Edge Integration or
IoT Streaming 

IoT Streaming

Sensor reading or similar

Edge Integration or
IoT Streaming 

Here, the word "trigger" is more indicative. Of course, we may have other types of triggers - i.e. building custom Event Notifications based on some other type of ERP events or even based on scheduled jobs.

Final note

If you have noticed some inconsistency in this article, then you are right!

Let me now explain. If we talk about stream or continuous flow of Data, to be absolutely correct, we may even say ‚Äì hey, this is not ‚Äúreally‚Äù Event-Driven Architecture, as there is no Event triggering anything‚Ä¶ Technically, this is correct! But EDA is about Event Broker ‚Äì and modern Event Brokers are capable of handling huge volumes of messages per second (or less) so, whether we are talking of IT Business Data, or OT continuous flow of Data, we would Orchestrate it (or provide Choreography ‚Äì to be more precise) using an Event Broker.

So, let us adopt ‚Äì no matter whether we publish message payloads based on Events, or they are based on sensor reading; no matter if it is small, or large message; no matter if clients are Business Systems, or clients are IoT devices ‚Äì if we are using an Event Broker, we will consider this to be EDA integration model.

Well, this is at least my view, and my (simplified) "understanding"...

entry.title: SAP Integration Suite ‚Äì Generative AI based Integration Flow Generation with Mediation Steps
entry.content:
Introduction

SAP Integration Suite - Cloud Integration version 6.69.**, comes with an enhancement on Generative AI (GenAI) feature - GenAI based Integration Flow Generation with Mediations Steps.  This feature is an extension to GenAI based Integration Flow Generation as described in https://community.sap.com/t5/technology-blog-posts-by-sap/sap-integration-suite-generative-ai-based-integration-flow-generation/ba-p/13761166 . This feature will be available only in SAP Integration Suite Cloud Integration Premium Editions, on specific regions/data centres. This blog or product document will be updated with the list of regions/data centres once the rollout of this feature/software completes. 

This feature is forecasted to rollout in mid-September 2025 (these are tentative timelines, subjected to change as per internal phased rollout plan).

Update: Information about region-wise availability of this feature can be found in SAP Knowledge Base Article https://me.sap.com/notes/0003656393 

Enabling GenAI Based Integration Flow Generation feature

As tenant administrator of your premium edition tenant, you need to enable this feature in Settings page of SAP Integration Suite. Compared to steps mentioned in the earlier blog https://community.sap.com/t5/technology-blog-posts-by-sap/sap-integration-suite-generative-ai-based-integration-flow-generation/ba-p/13761166, there is an enhancement in the settings page and the GenAI settings have been moved to a dedicated sub-navigation item called Artificial Intelligence, screenshot of which has been provided below. To enable this feature, you need to agree to the relevant terms and conditions.

Below are the sample screenshots of the same

Note : Flow Step Recommendations is a AI (ML) related feature which was/is available in all editions of Integration Suite. It is a alway's ON feature and tenant administrator will not be able to switch it OFF.  For more information, checkout the blog post https://community.sap.com/t5/technology-blog-posts-by-sap/sap-cloud-integration-flow-step-recommendations/ba-p/13474550 

 

 

Generating Integration Flows with Mediation Steps

Once this feature is switched ON by the tenant administrator, you - as integration developer persona - can use this feature to generate integration flows. 

Now, you click on Add -> Integration flow menu in your package view, you will be given option for generating the integration flow with assistance from AI or create integration flow manually. 

Below are the screenshots of generating integration flows using generative AI.

If you observe the above screenshot, the description contains information about the components of the integration flow along with systems. This is the extension compared to previous feature version, wherein the generative AI backend layer recognises the components - also known as mediations steps - and generates the integration flow accordingly. 

Once the description is complete, click on send button.

The feature extension now also provides a detailed AI Response on what it has identified as systems, components and actions - kind of a reasoning - with which it will proceed for the integration flow generation. Click on Generate button. Below is the sample output of the generated integration flow.

As you can observe above screenshot, the generated integration flow has the flow steps which matches the components/mediation steps information provided in the integration flow requirement description as user input, along with that, integration flow is auto  aligned/auto formatted. The generative AI backend layer has provided proper names to flow steps/mediation steps as per the description, unlike static names like content modifier 1, message mapping 1 , which you might have observed when you manually drag-and-drop the flow elements and rename them - saves your time a lot. 

It has also generated resources, i.e., message mapping file for the message mapping flow step.

Currently, the generative AI backend layer is only generating empty/default resources., e.g., the generated message mapping file doesn't contain source and target schema structure as shown in the below screenshot.

The relevant resources's content like message mapping with schemas, groovy scripts with custom logic shall be supported in next upcoming increments. 

Summary

SAP Integration Suite ‚Äì Cloud Integration GenAI based integration flow generation with mediation steps feature will help you bootstrap and accelerate the integration development activity.

As mentioned in the summary section of previous blog https://community.sap.com/t5/technology-blog-posts-by-sap/sap-integration-suite-generative-ai-based-integration-flow-generation/ba-p/13761166 , this feature extension enhances the generative AI offering with mediations steps. Having said that, all is not complete yet. We noticed accuracy issues sometimes/in some cases - as with LLMs - in our internal validation. Some of the observations are : missing accuracy in generated integration flow and its mediation steps names/sequence connections, missing discovered UCL system's configuration with outbound adapters (please check previous blog on UCL approach in GenAI based Integration flow generation) and flow steps, empty/default resources like message mapping, groovy scripts, missing auto alignment/auto formatting, missing semantic connections for control flows (e.g. router, multicast) of generated integration flow.

We continue working on fixing accuracy issues as we make future releases, but the current extension in GenAI based Integration Flow generation with mediation steps should surely increase the integration flow developer efficiency.

entry.title: Agentic AI ‚Äì AI which finally makes sense?
entry.content:
‚ÄúA computer can never be held accountable, therefore a computer must never make a management decision.‚Äù ‚Äì IBM Training Manual, 1979[1][2]

So, where are we with AI now? Isn‚Äôt Agentic AI doing exactly what it isn‚Äôt supposed to do?

AI or ML or?

We are bombed with terms ‚Äì small break! Let‚Äôs digest this grocery of terms‚Ä¶

  • Data Science[3] is a broad interdisciplinary scientific field using scientific methods to extract knowledge and insights from the massive data sets. It uses both; traditional data mining, data analysis and statistical methods; as well as ML techniques, to accomplish the given tasks.
  • AI (Artificial Intelligence) is the broadest concept, aiming to create machines that can "think" and perform human-like tasks.
  • ML (Machine Learning)[3] is a subset of AI where algorithms learn from data without explicit programming, enabling predictions and pattern recognition. It does need Data Science to be employed first to clean, prepare and analyze unstructured big data
  • Deep Learning[4] is a type of ML based on artificial neural networks impersonating human ‚Äúthinking‚Äù.

Neither ML nor AI are something brand new. It is considered that earliest ML ‚Äúprogram‚Äù was introduced in the early 1950s (by Arthur Samuel). Mid 1950s was the time when AI somehow emerged as well. However, only in 2000s ML/AI started being more popular ‚Äì simply because machines could not cope with the complex ML/AI processing, before that time. The real break-through (sort-of) came only in 2012 with Deep-Learning. Everything else is now a ‚Äúlegend‚Äù‚Ä¶

Figure 1. Data Science as a discipline

Is this the correct relationship between ML and AI?

There are somewhat different views, but let‚Äôs stick with the one which is the most common; Deep Learning is a subset of ML, ML is subset of AI, and Data Science is here to ‚Äúhelp‚Äù them all. Still let me just mention ‚Äì some other interpretation would put ‚Äúall‚Äù under umbrella of Dats Science, while some views say that AI is only ‚Äúpartially overlapping‚Äù with ML and Deep Learning. However, we will (at least in this article) stay with the relationships as presented in this diagram.

Generative AI

AI is great, but next big evolution happened with Generative AI (or GenAI)[5].

So, what is Generative AI? While AI is very broad field of computer science focused on enabling machines to perform human-like tasks, Generative AI is a specialized subset of AI (or Traditional AI, as often referred) that creates new, original content such as text, images, or music ‚Äì impersonating human-like creativity.

When we talk about GenAI, sometimes we mixed it with LLM (Large Language Model) ‚Äì but this is, of course, not correct. GenAI encompasses various forms of content generation, while LLM is a foundation model for NLP (Natural Language Processing) tasks ‚Äì oriented to text understanding and generation only.

Both GenAI, in general, and LLM are in the essence based on Deep Learning models.

Figure 2. Generative AI

Whether we talk about text, or image or music creation, the flow is basically the same; there is a prompt (usually created by the user), invoking GenAI processing of the request to understand and generate appropriate content (i.e. text or answer on the specific inquiry), and finally there is a GenAI generated response returned to the requestor.

Agentic AI

And here we come to Agentic AI, next big hype ‚Äì AI which makes sense? AI which can make actual decisions!

In general, it is scary ‚Äì I admit. But at least, now we have a concept which can really, really be useful in the daily work. Do not take me wrong GenAI is also useful for quite a few things, but it was mostly limited to do some recommendations, suggestions etc.‚Äì it was more as an assistant helping us do the work, but we still had to make decisions and do the work by ourselves. But now with Agentic AI we actually have a tool which can make the decision and do the actual work. Yes, it is scary really ‚Äì but it is a reality, as well‚Ä¶

Agentic AI[6][7] is an AI system, with enhanced autonomy, enabling it to independently set goals, make decision on it, plan actions accordingly, and finally execute necessary tasks, without human intervention. Unlike Traditional AI, or ‚Äúonly‚Äù Generative AI, Agentic AI Systems are capable to understand complex context, learn from the interactions, and adapt to changing conditions. Within its ‚Äúcore‚Äù, Agentic AI Systems integrate LLMs ‚Äì to work together with other agents. Agents can be other ML models, but those could be also calls to external tools (i.e. like API calls, DB actions etc.). In the system, through AI Orchestration each agent is performing specific subset of tasks required to reach the overall goal.

Figure 3. Agentic AI System has ‚Äúbrain‚Äù, ‚Äúmemory‚Äù and ‚Äútools‚Äù

It is exactly because of ‚Äúagents‚Äù working with LLM ‚Äúbrain‚Äù, this approach is demonstrating high autonomy in solving problems; from understanding the context, invoking the right agents to perform ‚Äúmicro‚Äù tasks; aggregating all results, measure the success rate in meeting the goal, make the decision and execute the actions.

Agentic AI is focused on decisions as opposed to creating the content, like GenAI. Agentic AI does not rely on human prompts and does not require human supervision. But Agentic AI and GenAI tools work together, each of them takes their own role. In fact, Agentic AI could not do what it does, if there are no GenAI capabilities ‚Äì core of the Agentic AI System relies on GenAI to make actions on the initial prompts (or inputs invoking specific agents via AI Orchestration), evaluating responses received form the agents, and generating final human-like responses on the prompts (if such actions is needed).

Figure 4. An example of steps within Agentic AI System

In real terms, the process could look like this:

  1. Agentic AI System uses its brain (i.e. LLMs) to understand the context (i.e. understand that prompt is asking for the specific Sales Order status) and generate the content for the external tool agents (i.e. API call to the ERP system).
  2. Usually, Agentic AI System will also have memory to store past context ‚Äì to be smarter with similar prompts in future.
  3. AI Orchestration will invoke tools which will perform specific tasks (i.e. read the Sales Order detail from the ERP system, read LMD delivery status, retrieve knowledge from RAG or simply engage other agent) and return the results to the brain.
  4. All responses will be aggregated (i.e. if we are invoking several tools).
  5. Agentic AI brain may evaluate the conditions (if met) or it may measure success rate toward set goals (if satisfaction level reached).
  6. At the end, Agentic AI brain may trigger some actions, including providing response to the requester ‚Äìthis time it will create the content (i.e. human-like response with the Sales Order status).

Another typical example would be autonomous vehicles (or self-driving cars), where car AI must understand the complex context of the surrounding driving conditions, take the necessary inputs, and act toward reaching the goal. In this process car AI will make autonomous driving decisions and steer the vehicle accordingly.

This is why Agentic AI is Ai which actual does make sense ‚Äì as it actually can work for us‚Ä¶ Of course, will it (eventually) work only for us ‚Äì this is completely different topic ‚Äì which I will try to address in the separate article.

Some more practical examples, addressing some additional topics about A2A, MCP including some SAP specific topics like Content Based Agents vs. Code Based Agents ‚Äì I will also try to cover in the separate article.

And don‚Äôt worry. Agentic AI is current hype ‚Äì but AI is evolving, there will more and more ‚Äúhypes‚Äù in the future, I am quite certain‚Ä¶

Final Thoughts

So, Agentic AI makes decisions ‚Äì and not only that, but they also execute actions! Let‚Äôs think about future and ‚Äúreal‚Äù self-driving cars!

Then, are we actually violating the principles set by IBM in 1979? I am not going to answer this question, but answer seems to be quite straight-forward, right?

Welcome to the future‚Ä¶

entry.title: Part 2: Agentic AI ‚Äì Governance, risks and dilemmas
entry.content:
Agentic AI is jet another evolution of Traditional AI, right? It brings more than Generative AI (GenAI), but is also carries out some more risks as well‚Ä¶ It‚Äôs becoming ‚Äúsmart‚Äù, it‚Äôs making ‚Äúdecisions‚Äù ‚Äì and IBM told us in 1979 we shouldn‚Äôt let computers make ‚Äúdecisions‚Äù because computers cannot be ‚Äúaccountable‚Äù[1]!

I‚Äôve tried to explain the AI evolution path in my previous article (Agentic AI ‚Äì AI which finally makes sense?). Now, let‚Äôs talk about governance, risks and ethical dilemmas.

We should be aware of it, and we should try to address it ‚Äì in time‚Ä¶

Let‚Äôs start with dilemmas‚Ä¶

Agentic AI can make autonomous decisions and based on this it can execute some complex tasks ‚Äì also autonomously. This can be useful, yes ‚Äì for sure this is much more than just GenAI assistants, where we had to make the decision and execute task on our own. Now we can have real robotic personal assistants, or self-driving cars, or robotic support agents. Tomorrow (and this tomorrow can come very fast) we will have fully autonomous HR agents and procurement officers, as well as fully autonomous industrial and humanoid robots, and let‚Äôs say this loudly ‚Äì war robots as well (oh, I am sure bunch of people are already working on it, as we speak).

Figure 1. Are we concerned?

Dilemma is clear ‚Äì where does this lead us at the end? Are we, out of our curiosity (or need to simplify our lives?) producing something which can replace us, or worse?

I do not have an answer on this ‚Äì future is unwritten chapter ‚Äì we are writing it now.

Agentic AI is reality, and now we should find the best way to use it! But at the same time,  we must create our future in a smart and sustainable way ‚Äì and I hope we will.

Now, risks‚Ä¶

As per risks with Agentic AI, like with any AI or GenAI, there are some ‚Äústandard‚Äù risks, for sure. But here I see that primary risk, is the risk of misuse by design ‚Äì and this I link with the above dilemmas‚Ä¶ I am not referring only to wrong design (i.e. being bias), I am referring on more serious ‚Äúintentional‚Äù use for the ‚Äúwrong‚Äù cause. What kind of agents and robots do we want to build? How much autonomy do we really want to give to AI? Although there are many articles, there are effectively no binding principles and guidelines. We are still too much intrigued with Agentic AI (or AI in general) ‚Äì so no boundaries are set.

But it should be! As long as we do not set reasonable (and sustainable) boundaries, we are at (major?) risk.

Figure 2. Key Risks leading to shortcomings

For the ‚Äústandard‚Äù risks, we have all those any GenAI might have ‚Äì starting with security vulnerabilities like prompt injection and data poisoning, to model hallucinations. With Agentic AI both can lead not just to ‚Äúill‚Äù recommendations, but to ‚Äúbad‚Äù decisions and ‚Äúwrong‚Äù actions taken.

Additional risk, also starting with GenAI ‚Äì the more cognitive tasks we pass to AI, the less cognitive tasks we will execute ‚Äì this may not be good, in the long run. Similar with Agentic AI ‚Äì the more decisions and actions are done by AI, the more dependent we become ‚Äì again, this is not good for us, in the long run.

Are we aware of these risks? Well, we should be‚Ä¶

Can we improve ‚Äúthings‚Äù with good Governance?

The key aspect of any governance is to, among others, minimize any shortcomings of the new tools, methods, projects etc. How can we do this for Agentic AI?

  • How do we ensure that Agentic AI System has been built in the transparent and explainable way ‚Äì so we can easily understand its purpose and ability?
  • How do we ensure Agentic AI is fair and responsible ‚Äì that we do see it as non-bias in making decision?
  • How do we build-in accountability within Agentic AI System (even these are ‚Äúcomputers‚Äù) ‚Äì in a way humans can accept it (also avoiding misuse by design)?
  • How do we ensure Agentic AI System is safe to operate of ‚Äì prompt injection and data poisoning has been effectively prevented.

Many questions‚Ä¶ But what are the key governing principles we must follow?

First and the most important ‚Äì there are no strict or imposed principles and guidelines (at least not yet) what is that Agentic AI System (agent or robot) can and cannot do by design. So, if we talk about ‚Äúformal‚Äù misuse of the technology ‚Äì sorry there are none or close to none (at least formally) limitations. But ‚Äúinformally‚Äù yes ‚Äì there are those ‚Äúdilemmas‚Äù for potential misuse of the AI (by design).

While it looked like we were very far away from the ‚Äúreal‚Äù AI (it was just a hype, right?) we did not care too much about putting any ‚Äúlegislation‚Äù. However, now things do not look so distant... The closer we come to real technology break-through toward autonomous robotics ‚Äì thighs are becoming more and more controversial.

So how to build AI, and especially Agentic AI (or some further evolutions) in a responsible manner?

Figure 3. Responsible AI is Human-centric

Let‚Äôs call this Responsible AI magic circle of ‚Äúinteraction‚Äù:

  • Agentic AI ‚Äúimposes‚Äù certain Risks
  • Risks do ‚Äúimpact‚Äù us, Human
  • Human must ‚Äúbuild‚Äù Governance rules and practices
  • Governance rules and practices are here to ‚Äúcontrol‚Äù Agentic AI

The fact currently there are no ‚Äúlegally‚Äù binding rules and principles, does not prevent us to set company or industry standards on our own ‚Äì let‚Äôs call it AI best practice.

If we talk about rules, let‚Äôs start thinking ‚Äì what is that we want to keep for ourselves? What is that we don‚Äôt want AI to do? How far are we from some futuristic scenarios and the need to build basic rules of robotics[2]? Maybe we should be ready to ‚Äúmove over‚Äù this mountain and embrace the fact ‚Äúfuture is happening right now‚Äù!

For principles, things are a bit more straight-forward, and previous AI experiences can really help us:

  1. Risk management: identifying, assessing, and mitigating the unique risks posed by both GenAI and autonomous agents. We should try to address all risks; from compliance risks and what and why do we build (to be transparent and explainable, to be fair and responsible, and ensure maximum possible accountability), to security risks (to be safe to operate).
  2. Continuous monitoring and auditing: agents/robots need to be monitored continuously to detect any deviation from intended behavior, any ethical issues, or security breaches. Also, audit trails and logging of agent decisions are vital for accountability, where (ideally) no agents/robots should access, alter and remove any audit trails and logs.
  3. Organizational structure: creating a cross-functional AI governance boards and bodies to create policies but also monitor adaptation of these policies in all Ai initiatives, with special focus on agents/robots.

All this, and more if needed, can be easily translated into any organization dealing with Agentic AI. Each organization will make adaptations on its own, of course ‚Äì but key is to be aware of risks and shortcomings, as well as all the potential benefits new Agentic AI technology is bringing. If we are aware, and we try addressing it with proper governance ‚Äì it‚Äôs a good start‚Ä¶

So, can we start all this and be open-minded?

entry.title: IDOCs are Still Safe for SAP S/4HANA - SAP Clean Core Extensibility Level B
entry.content:
Intro 

IDOCs are safe to use in SAP S/4HANA programs‚Äîand if anyone tells you otherwise, point them to this blog to learn more. IDOCs are now officially part of SAP Clean Core Extensibility! That‚Äôs the big news from updated SAP Guidelines (OSS Note 3578329 ‚Äì Frameworks, Technologies and Development Patterns in Context of Clean Core Extensibility).

This ends the myth that IDOCs are ‚Äúdead.‚Äù They are not. They‚Äôre preserved as SAP Clean Core Level B Extensibility, which means your existing IDOC investments are safe. Let‚Äôs explore four perspectives‚Äîintegration, monitoring and error handling, performance, and testing‚Äîto see where APIs are recommended first, and where IDOCs still bring value.

1. Integration Perspective

SAP‚Äôs recommendation for new development in S/4HANA is clear: use modern integration technologies such as APIs, events, or OData services. They are the strategic direction and best fit for greenfield or transformation projects. That said, not all projects require reinvention. If your business processes remain largely the same as in ECC, and the goal is to reduce cost and risk, IDOCs can still be used. They are not prohibited, and as long as an IDOC type is not listed as deprecated in the SAP Simplification List, it is safe:
https://help.sap.com/docs/btc/lean-sdt-best-practices/sap-s-4hana-simplification-analysis?locale=en-US Because IDOCs are now Clean Core Level B Extensibility, continuing with them is fully supported in SAP S/4HANA on-premise and SAP S/4HANA Private Cloud. They offer a pragmatic path to de-risk projects and leverage existing know-how.‚ÄÉ

2. Monitoring and Error Handling Perspective

For new interfaces, SAP recommends using AIF (Application Interface Framework) to handle monitoring, error management, and business validations. AIF provides a powerful, unified monitoring layer, and in many cases it comes license-free (for standard SAP interfaces delivered in namespaces like /SDSLS or /LEEDI, or in CFIN, Document Compliance, or S/4HANA Public Cloud). Where APIs are deployed, AIF bridges the gap between technical payloads and business-friendly monitoring.

IDOCs still have a strong card here: their monitoring capabilities are mature, well-known, and integrated into standard SAP transactions. Functional users know how to work with WE02, BD87, and standard reprocessing flows. This means less training, less overhead, and faster resolution in day-to-day operations.

In other words: AIF is recommended, but IDOCs deliver proven stability in monitoring and error handling.

3. Performance Perspective

APIs are the recommended way forward, but they come with a structural tradeoff: their payloads are larger and typically handle transactions individually. This makes them more verbose and sometimes less efficient for high-volume use cases. IDOCs, in contrast, have long supported bundling, batching, and parallel processing at scale. They‚Äôve been the backbone of high-volume EDI and SAP-to-SAP integrations for decades, and their ability to handle millions of documents daily is field-proven. So while APIs are the strategic choice for new designs, IDOCs remain a safe performance option for scenarios with heavy data throughput.

4. Testing Perspective

Testing support for APIs exists (for example, with SXI_MONITOR), but it is more technical and often requires additional training for functional teams. For IDOCs, simulation and reprocessing are familiar to almost every SAP functional consultant. Tools like WE19 and BD87 make IDOC testing and troubleshooting accessible, reducing dependency on specialist skills.

For projects that need to standardize and automate testing across both APIs and IDOCs, solutions like Int4 Suite provide simulation and test automation capabilities that unify all SAP integration scenarios. You can learn more on how to test and simulate SAP integrations in this SAP learning Course: Avoid SAP S/4HANA Project Delays with Third-Party Systems Service Virtualization So while APIs are recommended for new developments, IDOCs still offer ease of testing and proven tooling, especially in brownfield projects.

Conclusion

The strategic path forward in SAP S/4HANA is built on APIs, events, and frameworks like AIF. That‚Äôs the official recommendation, and it should guide greenfield and transformation projects. But IDOCs are far from obsolete. They are officially part of Clean Core extensibility, safe to use in both on-premise and private cloud, and carry unique advantages in performance, monitoring, and ease of testing. That makes them not only supported, but still a pragmatic and safe choice when the situation calls for stability, cost reduction, and risk mitigation.

entry.title: Int4 Suite Agents Empowers Functional Consultants To Test Integrated SAP S/4HANA Business Processes
entry.content:
Introduction 

Integrated business processes are the bloodstream of SAP systems. Every Sales Order, Purchase Order, Delivery, and Invoice has to flow smoothly, not just within SAP, but across EDI partners (customer, vendors, 3PL partners) banks, warehouses, tax portals.

Here‚Äôs the paradox: SAP S/4HANA projects have plenty of sophisticated automation tools, but they rarely help functional consultants in their manual tests. Instead, those tools get pushed into the narrow niche of automation testers. Functional consultants treat them like mythical dragons, complicated, dangerous, and likely to drag them away from their real work into procedural swamps.

The result? Slow testing cycles, dependency on integration specialists, and endless waiting for external partners to provide messages or confirmations.

Changing the story with simulation agents

The better path is not to force functional consultants into scripting or automation frameworks, but to give them simulation agents that mimic the system environment.

Instead of saying: ‚Äúlearn a test framework and run automated scripts,‚Äù we can say: ‚Äúhere are agents that simulate your missing EDI partner, your unavailable 3rd party/legacy system and you can test with them right now.‚Äù

This changes the game:

  • No competition with automation teams.
  • No learning curve with complex frameworks and procedural delays.
  • Consultants get something they instantly understand: realistic test conditions on demand, using actual historical production data.

How Int4 Suite Agents Work

With Int4 Suite, simulation agents provide a simple interface: the consultant performs the transaction in SAP, the agent feeds in authentic historical test data, and then automatically checks whether the newly generated EDI or non-EDI message matches what was sent in production.

Below are examples of key agents and how they fit into typical integrated OTC and P2P processes

Figure - meet the Int4 Suite Agents 

EDI Partner Agent (based on historical data)

Role: Replays authentic production EDI messages from trading partners (ORDERS, DESADV, INVOIC).

How it works:

  • Consultant performs the transaction in SAP (e.g., creates delivery, sends invoice).
  • Agent provides historical test data from previously exchanged documents.
  • Agent automatically compares the newly generated EDI message with the production one for a similar case.

OTC examples:

  • Consultant in the OTC team replays historical ORDERS from the largest customer and verifies whether, after pricing condition changes, the system still calculates correctly.
  • Consultant tests goods receipt with historical DESADV data; agent compares the new EDI message against the production one.
  • Consultant issues a sales invoice (INVOIC) and agent validates it against the original production invoice, checking VAT rules.

Figure - Select Historical EDI messages from Production system which need to be rerun on Test System 

P2P examples:

  • Consultant creates a purchase order; agent provides a historical ORDRSP where the supplier delivered partially, then compares the new outbound message.
  • Agent simulates a supplier INVOIC and verifies whether workflows behave the same after configuration changes.

Figure - manipulate the historical/production landscape EDI message data before sending that to the test environment

Unavailable System Agent (Non-SAP)

Role: Simulates external systems (banks, customs, WMS/TMS, tax portals) with historical production communications.

How it works:

  • Consultant runs the business process in SAP.
  • Agent injects historical test data from the external system.
  • Agent compares the new outbound message with the original production one.

OTC examples:

  • Consultant tests e-invoicing using a historically rejected invoice; agent checks whether the new output matches the original and if the new rules handle it.
  • Consultant tests shipment confirmations with historical WMS responses.

P2P examples:

  • Consultant tests bank payments; agent supplies historical payment files and checks the new output structure.
  • Consultant tests tax submissions; agent provides historical records and compares new vs. old messages.

Figure - Display the historical EDI data used on production landscape before rerunning that on the test environment 

Historical Data Agent

Role: The production message librarian, replays large volumes or special cases directly from production.

How it works:

  • Consultant triggers transactions in SAP (bulk orders, invoices, returns).
  • Agent provides the historical payloads.
  • Agent verifies test messages against the production equivalents.

OTC examples:

  • Consultant replays a ‚ÄúBlack Friday‚Äù scenario with 10,000 ORDERS; agent validates each new EDI message against its production twin.
  • Consultant tests credit memo flows from historical complaint cases.

Figure ‚Äì run many historical messages on the test environment for bulk testing purposes 

P2P examples:

  • Consultant tests bulk supplier invoices; agent validates the outputs against production.
  • Consultant tests blocked spare-parts orders with historical references.

Integration Consultant Agent

Role: A technical assistant that retrieves and compares messages from middleware layers (PI/PO, CPI).

How it works:

  • Consultant executes the business process in SAP.
  • Agent fetches the historical integration payload.
  • Agent highlights differences between new and historical messages.

OTC examples:

  • Consultant creates a sales order; agent compares the IDoc/XML message with the historical SAP Integration Suite payload.
  • Agent highlights mapping differences at field level after configuration changes.

Figure ‚Äì fetch an EDI payload produced by the integration platform (SAP Integration Suite, etc.) from a newly created business document and compare with the historical one from the production landscape without asking SAP Integration Consultant for help 

P2P examples:

  • Consultant enters a supplier invoice; agent pulls historical Ariba-CPI payload and checks consistency.
  • Agent validates purchase order messages across production and test runs.

Why it matters for SAP S/4HANA projects

In S/4HANA transformations, the external world doesn‚Äôt care about your internal redesigns. Customers, suppliers, and banks still expect exactly the same messages they used to get. Outbound and inbound interfaces are fragile bridges that must remain stable.

By equipping functional consultants with Int4 Suite agents:

  • Test cycles shorten dramatically.
  • Reliance on external partners and scarce integration resources drops.
  • Confidence in end-to-end quality rises.

This isn‚Äôt about replacing automation experts or integration teams. It‚Äôs about enabling functional consultants to independently confirm that what leaves SAP (or comes into it) is still what the outside world expects.

It‚Äôs the missing puzzle piece for smooth, low-friction testing of integrated business processes in SAP transformations.

entry.content:
Integration Between SAP CPI and SAP DataSphere (JDBC Connection)

JDBC ‚Äì JAVA DATABASE CONNECTIVITY

Why Recommendation for JDBC Over OData API :
JDBC is recommended over OData when consuming large-scale records (e.g., 100,000+) because JDBC streams data directly from the database with better performance and less overhead, while OData is optimized for lightweight, paginated, service-based access.

Problem statement: 3337495 - OData API returns less records than expected due paging
